Resource.name: Apartheid in South Africa
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students survey the historical roots of segregation in South African society, investigate the history of apartheid from 1948 to 1994, and propose a new South African holiday to commemorate apartheid's downfall. They investigate the history of white European rule in South Africa, determine key events in the downfall of apartheid, choose the most significant event, and justify the choice in writing.

Resource.name: Vector Algebra
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students develop an understanding of vectors, vector algebra, and the component method of adding vectors. They explore the purpose of vectors and their meaning, distinguish between vectors and scalars, recognize why vector algebra is important, learn how to break vectors into components, and understand what these components mean.

educationalAlignment.description: Explain the factors that influence the dynamics of falling objects and projectiles.

Measured quantities can be classified as either vector or scalar.

The student will perform operations with vectors in the coordinate plane and solve real-world problems, using vectors. This will include the following topics: operations of addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication, and inner (dot) product; norm of a vector; unit vector; graphing; properties; simple proofs; complex numbers (as vectors); and perpendicular components.

Objects change their motion only when a net force is applied. Laws of motion are used to calculate precisely the effects of forces on the motion of objects. Resource.name: Quadratic Equations & Inequalities: Internet Sites
Resource.description: Intended for Intermediate level students, this lesson enhances writing and presentation skills as well as vocabulary. It requires some familiarity with the use of the past tense. Students read fables in the target language, identify elements of a fable, and write and present an original fable.

Resource.name: The Native American Reeducation Movement
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students research the government's attempt to assimilate Native Americans through education programs at the turn of the 20th century and the impact of this movement on Native American children and culture. They compare and contrast traditional Native American education with education in the boarding schools, and analyze the impact that these schools had upon the culture and lifestyles of the Native American children that attended them.

Resource.name: Earthquakes & Volcanoes: Patterns of Fury
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students explore the destructive effects of plate tectonics. They conduct research to determine the location of earthquakes and active volcanoes, plot sites of geologic activity on a world map, and determine the correlation between the resulting plot and lithospheric plate boundaries.

educationalAlignment.description: evaluate the role of plate tectonics with respect to long-term global changes in Earth's subsystems such as continental buildup, glaciation, sea level fluctuations, mass extinctions, and climate change.
Plate motions have resulted in global changes in geography, climate, and the patterns of organic evolution.

The convection circulation of the earth’s mantle slowly moves the solid crustal sections of the earth’s continents and ocean basins over the denser, hot layers beneath—separating in some areas and pressing against one another in other areas resulting in plate collisions— mountain building—volcanic activity—islands.

Resource.name: Language as Power in Lan Cao's Monkey Bridge
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students recognize the role of language in attaining identity. They distinguish between literal and figurative language, analyze a literary passage, illustrate a maxim through a written narrative, and edit writing through peer review.

Resource.name: Distance Formula in Washington, DC
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students use the 2D distance formula to find approximate distances on a map. They transfer data from an online map to a rectangular coordinate graph, determine an appropriate scale for the graph, and use the 2D distance formula to determine the minimum distances between various points of interest in Washington, DC.

Mathematically proficient students start by explaining to themselves the meaning of a problem and looking for entry points to its solution. They analyze givens, constraints, relationships, and goals. They make conjectures about the form and meaning of the solution and plan a solution pathway rather than simply jumping into a solution attempt. They consider analogous problems, and try special cases and simpler forms of the original problem in order to gain insight into its solution. They monitor and evaluate their progress and change course if necessary. Older students might, depending on the context of the problem, transform algebraic expressions or change the viewing window on their graphing calculator to get the information they need. Mathematically proficient students can explain correspondences between equations, verbal descriptions, tables, and graphs or draw diagrams of important features and relationships, graph data, and search for regularity or trends. Younger students might rely on using concrete objects or pictures to help conceptualize and solve a problem. Mathematically proficient students check their answers to problems using a different method, and they continually ask themselves, ""Does this make sense?"" They can understand the approaches of others to solving complex problems and identify correspondences between different approaches.

Building on the inherent problem-solving abilities of people over time, students can understand that mathematics is relevant when studied in a cultural context that applies to real-world situations and environments.

Mathematically proficient students start by explaining to themselves the meaning of a problem and looking for entry points to its solution. They analyze givens, constraints, relationships, and goals. They make conjectures about the form and meaning of the solution and plan a solution pathway rather than simply jumping into a solution attempt. They consider analogous problems, and try special cases and simpler forms of the original problem in order to gain insight into its solution. They monitor and evaluate their progress and change course if necessary. Older students might, depending on the context of the problem, transform algebraic expressions or change the viewing window on their graphing calculator to get the information they need. Mathematically proficient students can explain correspondences between equations, verbal descriptions, tables, and graphs or draw diagrams of important features and relationships, graph data, and search for regularity or trends. Younger students might rely on using concrete objects or pictures to help conceptualize and solve a problem. Resource.name: The Influence of the Declaration of Independence on Stanton's Declaration of Sentiments
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students explore Elizabeth Cady Stanton's decision to model her statement of women's rights, the Declaration of Sentiments, on Thomas Jefferson's Declaration of Independence, and they respond to questions that ask them to evaluate the effect and the wisdom of that decision. They practice a close reading of literary text, compare the prose style and content of two nonfiction literary selections, and draw conclusions about the quality of the selections based on the comparison of prose style and content.

Resource.name: Ideas for Generating Writing

Resource.name: World War II: Memories of the Holocaust
Resource.description: Through this lesson, students examine primary-source information in order to personally reflect on the Holocaust. They develop a broad but detailed overview of the Holocaust, examine the testimonies of Holocaust survivors and select representative examples, and reflect on the Holocaust and provide personal commentary.

educationalAlignment.description: Describe the background, course, and consequences of the Holocaust, including its roots in the long tradition of Christian anti-Semitism, 19th century ideas about race and nation, and Nazi dehumanization of the Jews.
Analyze conflict, cooperation, and interdependence among individuals, groups, and institutions (e.g., gender roles, social stratification, racial/ethnic bias)
Holocaust
The Nazi Holocaust: the extermination of Jews, Poles, other Slavs, Gypsies, disabled, and others
Identify Nazi ideology, policies, and consequences that led to the Holocaust.
Analyze the restriction of individual rights and the use of mass terror against populations in the Soviet Union, Nazi Germany, and occupied territories.
anti-Semitism and the Holocaust
Military Conflicts (e.g., World War I, World War II, Persian Gulf War)
Discuss the causes and effects of various compromises and conflicts in American history.

Investigate development and enactment of Hitler’s “final solution” policy, and the responses to genocide by the Allies, the U.S. government, international organizations, and individuals (e.g., liberation of concentration camps, Nurembergwar crimes tribunals, establishment of state of Israel).
Describe and analyze the origins and consequences of slavery, genocide, and other forms of persecution, including the Holocaust

explaining economic and political causes, major events, and identifying leaders of the war, with emphasis on Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Douglas MacArthur, George Marshall, Winston Churchill, Joseph Stalin, Adolf Hitler, Hideki Tojo, and Hirohito;

analyze major issues of World War II, including the Holocaust; the internment of German, Italian, and Japanese Americans and Executive Order 9066; and the development of conventional and atomic weapons;

Cite specific textual and visual evidence to examine the causes, course, and effects of the Holocaust; and compare and contrast eyewitness accounts of camp inmates, survivors, liberators, and perpetrators; and, summarize world responses resulting in the Nuremberg Trials and the move to establish a Jewish homeland in Palestine.
Assess how the war expanded beyond military targets to civilian centers.

Twentieth Century Genocide – Use various sources including works of journalists, journals, oral histories, films, interviews, and writings of participants to analyze the causes and consequences of the genocides of Armenians, Romas (Gypsies), and Jews, and the mass exterminations of Ukrainians and Chinese.

Cite specific textual and visual evidence to analyze the series of events affecting the outcome of World War II including major battles, military turning points, and key strategic decisions in both the European and Pacific Theaters of operation including Pearl Harbor, the D-Day Invasion, development and use of the atomic bomb, the island-hopping strategy, the Allied conference at Yalta, and the contributions of Generals MacArthur and Eisenhower.
Understand conditions, actions and motivations that contribute to conflict and cooperation within and among nations.
Analyze the causes, course, and effects of World War I and World War II on the world.

Explain the background of the Holocaust (including its roots in 19th century ideas about race and nation); the dehumanization of the Jews through law, attitude, and actions such as badging, ghettoization, and killing processes; and how the Nazi persecution of gypsies, homosexuals, and others who failed to meet the Aryan ideal.
World War II devastated most of Europe and Asia, led to the occupation of Eastern Europe and Japan, and began the atomic age.

examines the nature of totalitarianism in fascist Germany and communist Soviet Union (e.g., one party rule; systematic violation of human rights, secret police, state supremacy over individual rights, role of private property, class structure).
the 1967 and 1973 wars between Israel and neighboring Arab states

Understand how the forces of nationalism developed in the Middle East, how the Holocaust affected world opinion regarding the need for a Jewish state, and the significance and effects of the location and establishment of Israel on world affairs.
Describe the effects of World War II.

Explaining conditions, actions, and motivations that contribute to conflict within and among individuals, communities, and nations (e.g., economic conditions, religious beliefs, political repression).
identify various parties and analyze their interest in conflicts from selected historical periods;

Analyze the global causes, course, and consequences of World War II and the post-war events (e.g., worldwide depression, totalitarian and militaristic regimes, Holocaust, political and social change in the Middle East, development of the United Nations, Cold War)
The Nuremberg war crimes trials; later trials of other Nazi criminals, e.g., Eichmann, Barbie
analyzing the major turning points and unique characteristics of the war
World War II
Use of atomic weapons changed the nature of war, altered the balance of power and began the nuclear age.
Treaties and agreements at the end of World War II changed national boundaries and created multinational organizations.
The Holocaust and its impact;
Explain the entry, the major battles, and the effects of World War II.
Examine causes, course, and consequences of World War II on the United States and the world.
Oppression and discrimination resulted in the Armenian Genocide during World War I and the Holocaust, the state-sponsored mass murder of Jews and other groups, during World War II.

Analyze the increase in economic and military competition among nations in terms of the influences of nationalism, imperialism, militarism, and industrialization (e.g., Ottoman Empire, Japanese Empire, Prussian Empire, the German Empire, ""Have and Have Nots"" of Europe, industrial America, etc.).
Compare the varying perspectives of victims, survivors, bystanders, rescuers, and perpetrators during the Holocaust.
Understand concepts such as chronology, causality, change, conflict, and complexity to explain, analyze, and show connections among patterns of historical change and continuity.

Explain how World War II and the Holocaust led to the creation of international organizations (i.e., the United Nations) to protect human rights, and describe the subsequent impact of these organizations.

Analyze the Nazi policy of pursuing racial purity, especially against the European Jews; its transformation into the Final Solution; and the Holocaust that resulted in the murder of six million Jewish civilians.
the Great Depression and World War II [1929-1945];
Assess the consequences of global war on the world.
Identify and analyze the causes, events and consequences of World War II.
Analyzes the multiple causal factors of conflicts in world history (1450 ? present).
